attachments.title: Widely Used Software Company May Be Entry Point for Huge U.S. Hacking
attachments.author_name: By Nicole Perlroth, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
attachments.text: Russian hackers may have piggybacked on a tool developed by JetBrains, which is based in the Czech Republic, to gain access to federal government and private sector systems in the United States.
attachments.fallback: The New York Times Widely Used Software Company May Be Entry Point for Huge U.S. Hacking

text: ooof glad I don't use that puppy anymore

elements.text: ooof glad I don't use that puppy anymore

text: Would something like this be possible in Julia if a bad actor could replace some part of a package the hack target is using? Let’s say the target is using package X, and it’s modified. The modification replaces some key part of Julia elsewhere, maybe compiler, maybe arithmetic, or something else. The stated functionality of X as such would have nothing to do with that key functionality, but would be perhaps a pretty printing or some other convenience package, or it could be a package with very few users.

The modification replaces some key part of Julia elsewhere, maybe compiler, maybe arithmetic, or something else. text: the reproducible builds project works towards this: <https://reproducible-builds.org/>

text: Well Packages can do very disastrous things, so adding a package is already an attack vector
